section: Domini shall pay the entire salaries and wages of all of the Trust's Trustees, officers and agents who devote part or all of their time to the affairs of Domini or its affiliates, and the wages and salaries of such persons shall not be deemed to be expenses incurred by the Trust for purposes of this Section 2. The Trust shall pay all of its operating expenses, including but not limited to fees due the Sponsor under this Agreement, compensation of Trustees not affiliated with the Sponsor, governmental fees, including but not limited to Securities and Exchange Commission fees and state "blue sky" fees; interest charges; taxes and related charges; membership dues of the Trust in the Investment Company Institute and other professional or industry associations; fees and expenses of the Trust's independent auditors and accountants, of legal counsel and any transfer agent, distributor, shareholder servicing agent, recordkeeper, registrar or dividend disbursing agent of the Trust; expenses of distributing, issuing and redeeming shares and servicing shareholder accounts; expenses of preparing, printing and mailing prospectuses and statements of additional information, reports, notices, proxy statements and reports to shareholders and governmental officers and commissions; expenses connected with the execution, recording and settlement of portfolio security transactions; insurance premiums; fees and expenses of the Trust's custodian for all services to the Trust, including safekeeping of funds and securities and maintaining required books and accounts; expenses of calculating the net asset value of shares of the Trust; expenses of shareholder meetings; and expenses relating to the issuance, registration and qualification of shares of any series of the Trust.
explanation: The text contains structural flaws as it presents a long, unbroken sentence listing various expenses. The lack of clear structure makes it difficult to quickly understand which expenses are the responsibility of the Trust. This hinders comprehension and could lead to disputes over expense allocation.

section: Domini shall pay the entire salaries and wages of all of the Trust's Trustees, officers and agents who devote part or all of their time to the affairs of Domini or its affiliates, and the wages and salaries of such persons shall not be deemed to be expenses incurred by the Trust for purposes of this Section 2. The Trust shall pay all of its operating expenses, including but not limited to fees due the Sponsor under this Agreement, compensation of Trustees not affiliated with the Sponsor, governmental fees, including but not limited to Securities and Exchange Commission fees and state "blue sky" fees; interest charges; taxes and related charges; membership dues of the Trust in the Investment Company Institute and other professional or industry associations; fees and expenses of the Trust's independent auditors and accountants, of legal counsel and any transfer agent, distributor, shareholder servicing agent, recordkeeper, registrar or dividend disbursing agent of the Trust; expenses of distributing, issuing and redeeming shares and servicing shareholder accounts; expenses of preparing, printing and mailing prospectuses and statements of additional information, reports, notices, proxy statements and reports to shareholders and governmental officers and commissions; expenses connected with the execution, recording and settlement of portfolio security transactions; insurance premiums; fees and expenses of the Trust's custodian for all services to the Trust, including safekeeping of funds and securities and maintaining required books and accounts; expenses of calculating the net asset value of shares of the Trust; expenses of shareholder meetings; and expenses relating to the issuance, registration and qualification of shares of any series of the Trust.
explanation: The legal terms within Section 2 suffer from structural flaws. The lengthy sentence detailing the Trust's operating expenses lacks clear organization, making it difficult to ascertain the exact scope of the Trust's financial responsibilities. This structural deficiency in the legal terminology increases the risk of misinterpretation and disputes regarding which expenses fall under the Trust's obligation.

section: For the services to be rendered and facilities to be provided by the Sponsor hereunder, the Trust shall pay Domini a mutually agreed upon fee.
explanation: The phrase "mutually agreed upon fee" is ambiguous because it does not specify when and how this fee is to be determined. It lacks details regarding the frequency of fee adjustments, the process for negotiation, or any mechanisms for resolving disagreements. This ambiguity could lead to disputes about the amount and timing of payments.

section: For the services to be rendered and facilities to be provided by the Sponsor hereunder, the Trust shall pay Domini a mutually agreed upon fee.
explanation: The compensation clause lacks clarity regarding how the 'mutually agreed upon fee' will be determined. It does not specify any objective criteria or industry standards to guide the negotiation process, making it difficult to enforce under state or national law. The absence of a clear framework for fee determination creates a legal ambiguity that could lead to disputes over reasonable compensation.
